Title: Randomised Controlled Trial of Augmented Reality Headset for Training in Acetabular Component Positioning

Background: Accurate implant orientation is essential in arthroplasty to reduce wear and increase stability. This study assesses the effectiveness of an augmented reality (AR) headset as a training tool for acetabular component positioning in simulated total hip arthroplasty (THA).

Methods: A randomised controlled trial was conducted with 24 final-year medical students applying to surgery residency programs, with no prior arthroplasty experience. Participants were randomised into two groups: one trained using an AR headset with live holographic feedback, and the other received hands-on training from an expert hip arthroplasty surgeon. The primary outcome was the orientation error in degrees between planned and achieved orientations, measured over four weekly sessions. Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed. Blinding was not applicable.

Results: All 24 participants completed the study. The AR group had a mean orientation error of 6° ± 4°, while the surgeon group had 1° ± 1° (p < 0.001). Both groups showed significant improvement over the sessions, with no significant difference in final accuracy (mean difference 1.2°, 95% CI, -1.8 to 4.2°; p = 0.281). In post-training evaluations, 11 of 12 participants expressed willingness to use the AR platform for developing visuospatial skills, and 10 of 12 for procedure-specific rehearsals. No adverse events were reported.

Interpretation: The AR headset provided comparable accuracy to expert training in acetabular component positioning. Participants found the AR platform valuable for developing visuospatial skills and procedure-specific rehearsals. The study supports the feasibility of AR as an adjunct to traditional training. Further research is needed to evaluate its application in other arthroplasty skills and real surgery.
